instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Early 2013 13" MacBook Pro Fans running full speed. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Machine turns on and chimes and will boot to desktop. Charges, etc... just fine.

This machine has the fans running full speed.

I've run ASD and I get these sensor errors:

TA0P -- Ambient Air Sensor (ERROR - SMC IO FAILED)
TA1P -- DC-IN Proximity for Airflow (ERROR - SMC IO FAILED)
TC0P -- CPU Proximity (ERROR - SMC IO FAILED)
TM0P -- DDR3 Proximity (ERROR - SMC IO FAILED)
TW0P -- AirPort Proximity (ERROR - SMC IO FAILED)

I have not been able to locate liquid damage (and I am the only one to take machine apart.)

Everything seems to run the way it should. It does not have an error on Ts0P for the trackpad, that test actually passes.

Is there a certain area of the board I should be focusing my efforts on?

Thank You!

threads.title: [SOLVED]Early 2013 13" MacBook Pro Fans running full speed. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Check <CHIP>U5570</CHIP>, 3.3V on pin 1, also check <SIGNAL>I2C_CPUTHMSNS_SDA</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>I2C_CPUTHMSNS_SCL</SIGNAL> and report values.....

threads.title: [SOLVED]Early 2013 13" MacBook Pro Fans running full speed. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Thank you for the reply. I will check these values once I am home in a few hours. The machine is in beautiful shape, would love to resurrect.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Early 2013 13" MacBook Pro Fans running full speed. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5570</CHIP> was just fine. Found some corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q7850</TRANSISTOR> and the backlit keyboard connector. Cleaned up the areas and BAM, no more loud fan and passes ASD now. Not sure why it would cause the sensor issues?? Any idea? But this can be marked fixed (not so much solved, but fixed)

Thanks!
